EDITORIAL.
ANY of our students have doubtless read with much interest the views
of Dr. Haupt about undergraduate studies as expressed in the Balti. lifo)sioslossogir .
v
more Sun of May 7th. Dr. Haupt's views, concisely expressed,
•
if -El.. seem to be mainly as follows:
(1), He advocates the shortening of
Iv• v
the collegiate course to two years, probably, however, adding an
.
V Afs
additional year to the school course. (2), He wishes to diminish
• V A.
✓
the
number of studies and give more time to fewer subjects. He
.
v
1r Iry s 10 if og s to •
adds that he does not see the use of a "student who intends to take
SZia• up the study of law or literature engaging his time with advanced
mathematics." (3), Dr. Haupt advocates the shortening of vacations,
a practice well established in German universities.
As to the first provision, we do not see the advantage in shortening the collegiate course
to two years, extending the high-school course one year further. The age of the man's getting
his degree, a matter which Dr. Haupt discusses at some length, will not be altered, and he
will fail to have had the broadening influences of college surroundings for a whole year. It is
true that the atmosphere of the- basement barber-shop may not be more intellectual than that
of the.high-school assembly hall, but surely no one can come to the University without some
appreciation of the intellectual surroundings and the more studious disposition of the men as
a whole. Dr. Haupt seems to draws his ideas direct from the apparently perfect "Gymnasium"
of Germany. There the men are worked like dray-horses up to the time of graduation, the
certificate from the "Gymnasium" being about equivalent to our degree of Bachelor of Arts.
From the "Gymnasium" a man enters college, and it is understood that, if he pleases, he may,
without shortening his time of residence, do almost no work at all for the first year or two. Is
this an advantage? Is this practice of relaxation, after years of hard labor, eventually of more
benefit to the student, as compared with the American system?
The second point is the most important of the three, and is one which seems to cause almost
endless discussion. We do not believe that a man entering.college should be forced to make his
decision as to his profession in life and be required immediately to follow a prescribed course
during his college career, the whole acting as a sort of serial in which the professional school
becomes only the continuation of work already begun along practically the same lines. We
think, however, that if a student has finally decided on his profession by the end of his Freshman year, he should be given full liberty to follow only courses bearing directly on his object,
with a minimum of required courses in general education. For example, if a student, at the
end of his Freshman year, declares his intention of a becoming a lawyer, and should be
greatly opposed to taking any one particular three-hour course as required by the catalogue,
ought not some arrangement be made for giving this student a shorter course in this subject,
a general knowledge of which, in all probability, is essential to a true "liberal education?"
14:

•

THE NEWS-LETTER.

We acknowledge that the question is a difficult one, but we think that a student who wishes to
do so, should be allowed to specialize to a greater degree than is now permitted.
As to the question of shortening the vacations, we think that this is scarcely a plan
adaptable for universities here in the South. The climate in this latitude is far different from
that of Germany and would scarcely admit of hard work on the part of college students during
the summer months. American students are too well used to the present condition of
affairs and would hardly be likely to approve the idea.
Upon the whole, we do not consider that the tendency to follow German methods for
undergraduates is liable to grow stronger at present, but we would like to see established a
rule giving permission to the undergraduate who desires to specialize an opportunity to do so
in his last three years of residence.
EVERAL times in the past, the Nitws-LETTER has published editorials on the lack of spirit at the games, but this time we wish to praise
the students for the great enthusiasm which was displayed at the
Swarthmore lacrosse game last Saturday. The cheering was well
organized and was greatly aided by the large number of Alumni who
1
were present. We are glad to see that the Alumni are taking such
active interest in the lacrosse games, and that these games are bean

But to return once more to the subject. The enthusiasm ran high, but this is no wonder because the game was one of the best that Hopkins has ever played.. It was a very good
plan to have a band out there, and we understand that this was made possible by the efforts of
Mr. Marcus in getting contributions. We hope that the students will keep up this good work,
and have a band at each of the remaining lacrosse games. We take this opportunity to mention, by way of a suggestion, that more of the students might carry megaphones with them, as
these make the yelling much more effective. It would also be advantageous to have a regular
cheer-leader—one who knows his business, and who is real energetic. If this spirit should
keep up and increase, we might hope to have, some day, college spirit equal to Princeton and
worthy of Hopkins.

fl\T another page of the NEWS-LETTER we publish a notice of the
decision of the Trustees of the University to provide for the degree
of Master of Arts. The conditions on which this degree may be
conferred are stated in the article. This will give many, who do not
care to take a Ph.D., for which it is necessary to do original research
work, the opportunity to get instructions in advanced studies. It is
thought by the Trustees that advantage will be taken of this course
by many teachers and instructors in Baltimore and the vicinity. It
seems strange to us, that the University had not long since provided
for the degree of A.M., and we are glad to see that the Trustees take
such an interest in the welfare of the University, and are doing everything they can to broaden
the scope of instructions.
There seems to be a rumor afloat to the effect that the University is going to provide
courses in Electrical Engineering and Law. We hope that these two schools will be established
in the near future. It seems that the University has enough wealth to do this, and if they
should establish these departments, it would increase the standing of the University and also
the size. While we are content with a small student body, we must admit that we should be
able to do more in the way of college activities if there were more students,

THE NEWS-LETTER.

PERCY TURNBULL MEMORIAL
LECTURES.
The next course of lectures on the Turnbull
foundation will be given by Professor Ramon
Menendez Pidal, of Madrid, Spain, on the
subject of Spanish Poetry, during the academic year 1908-1909. Senor Pidal is Professor of Spanish in the University of Madrid,
a member of the Royal Spanish Academy,
Associate Editor of the Revista de Archivos
and Cultura Espanola, one of the editors for
the Gesellschaft fur Romanische Literatur,
and a frequent contributor to such Romance
journals as Romania, Revue Hispanique, and
Zeitschrift fur Romanische Philologie,
Professor Pidal holds a pre-eminent position
as a Romance scholar and is the greatest living
authority on Spanish Epic Poetry and Ballad
Literature. Among his many contributions
to Spanish literature may be mentioned the
following works that bear directly on Spanish
poetry: Critical editions of the Poema del Cid,
Poema de Yucuf, Disputa del 0/ma, Auto de
los Reyes, Magos, and Cronica General; also
his critical studies, Leyenda de los Infantes de
Lara, Leyenda del Abad de Montemajor, and
Romancer°.
The lectures will be delivered in French;
the exact dates have not yet been agreed
upon.

DEGREE OF A. M.

The main object of this arrangement is to
meet the needs of those students who have not
the time necessary to enable them to fulfill the
requirements for the degree of Doctor of
Philosophy, and also of those who are not
interested specially in original investigation.
In general language, it may be said that the
principal requirement for the Doctor's degree
is the ability to carry to suCcessful completion
some original investigation; while the principal requirement for the Master's degree is the
careful pursuit of advanced studies in one or
more branches of knowledge for at least two
years.
It is hoped that some of the teachers of the
public schools of the State and City will find it
possible to take advantage of the opportunity
thus afforded.

HOW WE SAILED THE "SARAH ANN." balance on the gunwale, with nothing but
"We're off," said I, as amid the cheers of
Danny's three maiden aunts, his two pretty
cousins, and his mother, the "Sarah Ann"
sailed majestically past the stake-boat. The
"Sarah Ann" was perhaps eighteen feet long,
she carried one large leg-o-mutton sail, and
she had a certain appearance of strength and
sturdiness, which did not, however, prevent
Danny from firmly believing that she was by
far the swiftest bark that ever sailed the blue.
When the summer colony of our little bayside town arranged a "Grand Regatta," as
the hand-bills called it, Danny had hastened
to enter the 'Sarah Ann," and in preparation
for the great occasion he carefully washed out
the boat, and ordered from the city a gorgeous
blue pennant for her mast-head.
Danny decided to have me for his crew. He
informed me, when he broke the news, that
he really preferred to have a landsman on
board, for, as he said, those who are unlearned in nautical matters will not pester the
skipper with superfluous advice. I had sailed
in the 'Ann" once before, and as she seemed
quite safe and unsinkable, I agreed to be his
"bositiii tight and midshipmite."

Well, to take a fresh start, the day of the
race dawned fair and cool, and Danny's heart
was made glad by a thirty-mile gale which
covered the hay with sparkling white-caps.
We were to sail over a triangular course, three
miles before the wind, three with the wind
abeam, and three almost into the wind.
We were the last of the four boats to start,
but as we felt the "Sarah Ann" leap ahead,
gaining steadily upon our competitors, we
began to feel quite confident, and the skipper
forgot his official dignity sufficiently to sing a
few staves of "A Life on the Ocean Wave."
We were getting nearer and nearer to the
buoy, and suddenly Danny announced his intention to jibe. "Yes, sir," said he, "I'm
going to jibe, I don't care if it is blowing
hard. It takes more than a mere thirty-mile
breeze .to keep me from jibing!" I offered no
objeetion, for I didn't know what jibing
Meant; I soon found out. The skipper did
something with his tiller, something else to
his sail—and in two seconds I was about four
feet above the water, trying to keep my

the salt sea between me and the bottom.
Then we gently fell into the trough of the
wave, while the water that we had scooped
up rose to our knees in the boat.
When Danny had exhausted his vocabulary
he calmed a little and suggested that we bail
her out. Then we took a reef in the sail, to
prevent future mishaps, and got under way
once more. Then the wind lessened a bit,
and I was ordered to take the reefs out, while
Danny held the boat up into the wind. The
reef-knots refused to come out. "Cut 'em,"
cried the eaptain. "I've no knife," said I.
"No more have I," said Danny, and he proposed that I cut them with the edge of a can.
Dear reader, if you have never tried to cut a
quarter-inch wet cotton rope in a gale with a
tomato can, try it sometime. It took me ten
minutes to cut four, in which time our competitors gained many long yards on us.
"It's hopeless," said Danny; "I see we
can't win. I tell you what let's do, let's turn
the boat on her side and hang to her till we
get rescued. It'll be lots more dignified than
getting in an hour late." "Danny," I said;
"I admire the fertility of your imagination,
and I admit the brilliancy of your plan, but
you forget that I have on my watch." "Oh,
that's so," said he, reluctantly; "I did forget
your watch."
Having nothing more to discuss, we sat in.
gloomy silence, till at last we came in sight of
the pier at the finish. When we were a quarter of a mile from shore, the boat gave a sudden shudder and crunching sound which even
the landlubber crew knew to mean that we
were aground. I went to pull up the centreboard, but succeeded in getting only the rope,
which had broken where it was fastened to
the centre-board. "Gosh, we're stuck for
good now," said Danny, "we'll have to
anchor here till someone comes out for us."
So he went into the bow to throw the anchor
over; in the process a stray loop of the rope
caught him by the ankle and before my
startled eyes the skipper went over the side!
At the sight of Danny's bedraggled head
appearing above the water, I could restrain
myself no longer. I leaned against the mast
and roared till my sides ached and the tears
rolled down my cheeks.
"What's the joke, anyway?" said Danny,
innocently.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

A. D., 1978.
I had just finished my studying for the
Easter exams of 1908, and rolled into bed at
about 2.30 A. M. I was asleep in a few
minutes and through the night had a most
remarkable dream. Here it is:
It was May 1978, being an alumnus of
Johns Hopkins and having lived in Russia
for many years after graduation, I wished to
return to Baltimore and see if the University
had really "gone to Homewood." I was
much surprised when I reached the corner of
Linden avenue and Monument street to find
no signs of life around the once busy
"campus," but imagine my joy when I saw
a notice posted on one of the doors, stating
that the University had moved out to Homewood during the last month. At last! the
fond dream of our undergraduate days, the
University at "Homewood."
On one of the Baltimore Air Line Traction
Company aeroplanes I was at Homewood in a
few minutes and what a beautilul sight met
my gaze! The approach to the fine chapel
was lined with statues of famous Hopkins
men.

nickles had fallen; on the left was the trophyroom table, Walter's barber-chair and razor
with which so many of us had been tortured.
But what were those plaster of Paris casts?
On close examination I saw that one was a
cast of Dr. Greene's pleasant smile, and the
other a cast of Walter Blanck's hair, the only
way that it was possible to preserve it.
Further on was a glass case surrounded by an
iron railing, in it, on a piece of black velvet
—the gem of the whole Museum—Mrs.
"Bill" Stewart's glasses. Standing before
the case, I could almost hear her say, "Now
Mr. — you have not gotten that beaker
clean, you will have to wash it again." What
was that funny noise? It was only the
alarm-clock.

FRESHMAN BANQUET (?)
One of the most interesting happenings at
the University since the last issue of the
NEws-LETTER, took place on Friday, May
1st. On this day there was held in Donovan
Hall a meeting of the United Charities of
Baltimore. One of the best caterers in town
was entrusted with the care of providing refreshments, and many delectable dainties were
prepared for the guests. A very large crowd
had been expected, but only a comparatively
small number came. Many of the undergraduates found it convenient to attend this meeting as, oddly enough, the time for holding it
coincidedly exactly with the lunch hour of
many of our young men. In fact, the occasion proved a "salad day" for many of us,
and we trust that this worthy charity will
arrange to hold many such gatherings at the
University. We would like to ask that a
notice be posted several days in advance, so
that the representation of the University may
be as large as possible. Great regret was expressed at the absence of the Dean and other
members of the Faculty who would doubtless
enjoy attending these meetings as highly as
the average undergraduate. We are not able
to find words to express our appreciation of
the hospitality so freely extended by this
most liberal of charities, and heartily hope
we may be present at several similar gatherings during the remainder of the year.

UNIVERSITY NOTES.
SENSATION IN BIOLOGY MINOR.

DR. ANDREWS OFFERS AN AVENUE OF ESCAPE
FOR TIM STUDENTS.

Before the opening of the class in Biology
Minor, Dr. Andrews startled the class by the
announcement that he contemplated opening
a kindergarten in whittling. Doubtless he
thought this would be a valuable addition to
his already organized modelling class.
The doctor stated that some ambitious
students amused themselves by carving upon
the arms of their chairs. Diagrams of thirdday chicks be said were likely to confuse the
incoming class in Biology. However, he said,
as some of the students seemed unable to
restrain their instincts, he had supplied a
large amount of pine, oak and cherry, and
that those who found the lectures too boring,
might go outside.
[N. I3.—The author, of this, did not wait
to hear more].

Dr. T. W. Clocker, Assistant in Political
Economy, has been appointed Assistant Head
of the Research Department in the School for
Social Workers at Boston. The School for
Social Workers is maintained by Simmons
College and Harvard University. Dr. Jeffrey
R. Brackett, formerly of Baltimore, is Director
of the School. As Assistant Head of the
Research Department, Dr. Glocker will help
in the direction of the investigation into the
causes of poverty, which is being carried on
under a grant from the Russell Sage Foundation.

THE MEET WITH DICKINSON.
Our dual meet with Dickinson this year was
a great success, and the overwhelming manner in which the Varsity track team defeated
the visitors more than offsets the recent defeat
at the hands of the Navy. All of our men
were in fine condition. This is shown by
the fact that the wearers of the black and
blue scored first place in twelve out of the
thirteen events, the single exception being the
victory of Hess, for Dickinson, in the shotput.
Stollenwerck, Baily and Stewart captured
all the dash and middle distance events easily,
while Captain Brenton captured everything in
sight in the distance events. Bridgman must
also come in for his share of the honors, as he
came first in the 120-yard hurdles and the
pole-vault.
Our track team will go down to Virginia
tomorrow for a dual meet with the University
of Virginia. This will be the final track

event of the season, and let us hope that the
victory of last Saturday will be repeated.

MUSICAL CLUBS TAKE A TRIP.
At last the Musical Clubs got together and
took a trip to Waterbury, Md., which is about
ten miles from Annapolis. After much trouble,
the manager made enough fellows promise to
go on the trip. We could not hope to give a
concert without our star performer, Mr. Uhlig,
and, consequently, it was necessary to wait
until he recovered from his illness.
It was quite a novel experience. We took
the W. B. & A. electric car down to Waterbury, where we were met, not by carriages,
but by one lone man, who piloted us across
fields and along dusty country roads to the
town hall. When we arrived there everyone
was so hot that we thought we should not be
able to give the concert. However, after
cooling off for about half an hour, we opened
the performance with the University Ode, as
usual. The numbers were run off rapidly and
very successfully. During the intermission
ice cream was passed around, and we had
quite a sociable time.
After the concert we were brought back by
a special car. The car was. late leaving, and

adds that he does not see the use of a "student who intends to take
SZia• up the study of law or literature engaging his time with advanced
mathematics." (3), Dr. Haupt advocates the shortening of vacations,
a practice well established in German universities.
As to the first provision, we do not see the advantage in shortening the collegiate course
to two years, extending the high-school course one year further. The age of the man's getting
his degree, a matter which Dr. Haupt discusses at some length, will not be altered, and he
will fail to have had the broadening influences of college surroundings for a whole year. It is
true that the atmosphere of the- basement barber-shop may not be more intellectual than that
of the.high-school assembly hall, but surely no one can come to the University without some
appreciation of the intellectual surroundings and the more studious disposition of the men as
a whole. Dr. Haupt seems to draws his ideas direct from the apparently perfect "Gymnasium"
of Germany. There the men are worked like dray-horses up to the time of graduation, the
certificate from the "Gymnasium" being about equivalent to our degree of Bachelor of Arts.
From the "Gymnasium" a man enters college, and it is understood that, if he pleases, he may,
without shortening his time of residence, do almost no work at all for the first year or two. Is
this an advantage? Is this practice of relaxation, after years of hard labor, eventually of more
benefit to the student, as compared with the American system?
The second point is the most important of the three, and is one which seems to cause almost
endless discussion. We do not believe that a man entering.college should be forced to make his
decision as to his profession in life and be required immediately to follow a prescribed course
during his college career, the whole acting as a sort of serial in which the professional school
becomes only the continuation of work already begun along practically the same lines. We
think, however, that if a student has finally decided on his profession by the end of his Freshman year, he should be given full liberty to follow only courses bearing directly on his object,
with a minimum of required courses in general education. For example, if a student, at the
end of his Freshman year, declares his intention of a becoming a lawyer, and should be
greatly opposed to taking any one particular three-hour course as required by the catalogue,
ought not some arrangement be made for giving this student a shorter course in this subject,
a general knowledge of which, in all probability, is essential to a true "liberal education?"

THE NEWS-LETTER.

We acknowledge that the question is a difficult one, but we think that a student who wishes to
do so, should be allowed to specialize to a greater degree than is now permitted.
As to the question of shortening the vacations, we think that this is scarcely a plan
adaptable for universities here in the South. The climate in this latitude is far different from
that of Germany and would scarcely admit of hard work on the part of college students during
the summer months. American students are too well used to the present condition of
affairs and would hardly be likely to approve the idea.
Upon the whole, we do not consider that the tendency to follow German methods for
undergraduates is liable to grow stronger at present, but we would like to see established a
rule giving permission to the undergraduate who desires to specialize an opportunity to do so
in his last three years of residence.

fl\T another page of the NEWS-LETTER we publish a notice of the
decision of the Trustees of the University to provide for the degree
of Master of Arts. The conditions on which this degree may be
conferred are stated in the article. This will give many, who do not
care to take a Ph.D., for which it is necessary to do original research
work, the opportunity to get instructions in advanced studies. It is
thought by the Trustees that advantage will be taken of this course
by many teachers and instructors in Baltimore and the vicinity. It
seems strange to us, that the University had not long since provided
for the degree of A.M., and we are glad to see that the Trustees take
such an interest in the welfare of the University, and are doing everything they can to broaden
the scope of instructions.
There seems to be a rumor afloat to the effect that the University is going to provide
courses in Electrical Engineering and Law. We hope that these two schools will be established
in the near future. It seems that the University has enough wealth to do this, and if they
should establish these departments, it would increase the standing of the University and also
the size. While we are content with a small student body, we must admit that we should be
able to do more in the way of college activities if there were more students,

THE NEWS-LETTER.

PERCY TURNBULL MEMORIAL
LECTURES.
The next course of lectures on the Turnbull
foundation will be given by Professor Ramon
Menendez Pidal, of Madrid, Spain, on the
subject of Spanish Poetry, during the academic year 1908-1909. Senor Pidal is Professor of Spanish in the University of Madrid,
a member of the Royal Spanish Academy,
Associate Editor of the Revista de Archivos
and Cultura Espanola, one of the editors for
the Gesellschaft fur Romanische Literatur,
and a frequent contributor to such Romance
journals as Romania, Revue Hispanique, and
Zeitschrift fur Romanische Philologie,
Professor Pidal holds a pre-eminent position
as a Romance scholar and is the greatest living
authority on Spanish Epic Poetry and Ballad
Literature. Among his many contributions
to Spanish literature may be mentioned the
following works that bear directly on Spanish
poetry: Critical editions of the Poema del Cid,
Poema de Yucuf, Disputa del 0/ma, Auto de
los Reyes, Magos, and Cronica General; also
his critical studies, Leyenda de los Infantes de
Lara, Leyenda del Abad de Montemajor, and
Romancer°.
The lectures will be delivered in French;
the exact dates have not yet been agreed
upon.

DEGREE OF A. M.

The main object of this arrangement is to
meet the needs of those students who have not
the time necessary to enable them to fulfill the
requirements for the degree of Doctor of
Philosophy, and also of those who are not
interested specially in original investigation.
In general language, it may be said that the
principal requirement for the Doctor's degree
is the ability to carry to suCcessful completion
some original investigation; while the principal requirement for the Master's degree is the
careful pursuit of advanced studies in one or
more branches of knowledge for at least two
years.
It is hoped that some of the teachers of the
public schools of the State and City will find it
possible to take advantage of the opportunity
thus afforded.

HOW WE SAILED THE "SARAH ANN." balance on the gunwale, with nothing but
"We're off," said I, as amid the cheers of
Danny's three maiden aunts, his two pretty
cousins, and his mother, the "Sarah Ann"
sailed majestically past the stake-boat. The
"Sarah Ann" was perhaps eighteen feet long,
she carried one large leg-o-mutton sail, and
she had a certain appearance of strength and
sturdiness, which did not, however, prevent
Danny from firmly believing that she was by
far the swiftest bark that ever sailed the blue.
When the summer colony of our little bayside town arranged a "Grand Regatta," as
the hand-bills called it, Danny had hastened
to enter the 'Sarah Ann," and in preparation
for the great occasion he carefully washed out
the boat, and ordered from the city a gorgeous
blue pennant for her mast-head.
Danny decided to have me for his crew. He
informed me, when he broke the news, that
he really preferred to have a landsman on
board, for, as he said, those who are unlearned in nautical matters will not pester the
skipper with superfluous advice. I had sailed
in the 'Ann" once before, and as she seemed
quite safe and unsinkable, I agreed to be his
"bositiii tight and midshipmite."

Well, to take a fresh start, the day of the
race dawned fair and cool, and Danny's heart
was made glad by a thirty-mile gale which
covered the hay with sparkling white-caps.
We were to sail over a triangular course, three
miles before the wind, three with the wind
abeam, and three almost into the wind.
We were the last of the four boats to start,
but as we felt the "Sarah Ann" leap ahead,
gaining steadily upon our competitors, we
began to feel quite confident, and the skipper
forgot his official dignity sufficiently to sing a
few staves of "A Life on the Ocean Wave."
We were getting nearer and nearer to the
buoy, and suddenly Danny announced his intention to jibe. "Yes, sir," said he, "I'm
going to jibe, I don't care if it is blowing
hard. It takes more than a mere thirty-mile
breeze .to keep me from jibing!" I offered no
objeetion, for I didn't know what jibing
Meant; I soon found out. The skipper did
something with his tiller, something else to
his sail—and in two seconds I was about four
feet above the water, trying to keep my

the salt sea between me and the bottom.
Then we gently fell into the trough of the
wave, while the water that we had scooped
up rose to our knees in the boat.
When Danny had exhausted his vocabulary
he calmed a little and suggested that we bail
her out. Then we took a reef in the sail, to
prevent future mishaps, and got under way
once more. Then the wind lessened a bit,
and I was ordered to take the reefs out, while
Danny held the boat up into the wind. The
reef-knots refused to come out. "Cut 'em,"
cried the eaptain. "I've no knife," said I.
"No more have I," said Danny, and he proposed that I cut them with the edge of a can.
Dear reader, if you have never tried to cut a
quarter-inch wet cotton rope in a gale with a
tomato can, try it sometime. It took me ten
minutes to cut four, in which time our competitors gained many long yards on us.
"It's hopeless," said Danny; "I see we
can't win. I tell you what let's do, let's turn
the boat on her side and hang to her till we
get rescued. It'll be lots more dignified than
getting in an hour late." "Danny," I said;
"I admire the fertility of your imagination,
and I admit the brilliancy of your plan, but
you forget that I have on my watch." "Oh,
that's so," said he, reluctantly; "I did forget
your watch."
Having nothing more to discuss, we sat in.
gloomy silence, till at last we came in sight of
the pier at the finish. When we were a quarter of a mile from shore, the boat gave a sudden shudder and crunching sound which even
the landlubber crew knew to mean that we
were aground. I went to pull up the centreboard, but succeeded in getting only the rope,
which had broken where it was fastened to
the centre-board. "Gosh, we're stuck for
good now," said Danny, "we'll have to
anchor here till someone comes out for us."
So he went into the bow to throw the anchor
over; in the process a stray loop of the rope
caught him by the ankle and before my
startled eyes the skipper went over the side!
At the sight of Danny's bedraggled head
appearing above the water, I could restrain
myself no longer. I leaned against the mast
and roared till my sides ached and the tears
rolled down my cheeks.
"What's the joke, anyway?" said Danny,
innocently.

A. D., 1978.
I had just finished my studying for the
Easter exams of 1908, and rolled into bed at
about 2.30 A. M. I was asleep in a few
minutes and through the night had a most
remarkable dream. Here it is:
It was May 1978, being an alumnus of
Johns Hopkins and having lived in Russia
for many years after graduation, I wished to
return to Baltimore and see if the University
had really "gone to Homewood." I was
much surprised when I reached the corner of
Linden avenue and Monument street to find
no signs of life around the once busy
"campus," but imagine my joy when I saw
a notice posted on one of the doors, stating
that the University had moved out to Homewood during the last month. At last! the
fond dream of our undergraduate days, the
University at "Homewood."
On one of the Baltimore Air Line Traction
Company aeroplanes I was at Homewood in a
few minutes and what a beautilul sight met
my gaze! The approach to the fine chapel
was lined with statues of famous Hopkins
men.

nickles had fallen; on the left was the trophyroom table, Walter's barber-chair and razor
with which so many of us had been tortured.
But what were those plaster of Paris casts?
On close examination I saw that one was a
cast of Dr. Greene's pleasant smile, and the
other a cast of Walter Blanck's hair, the only
way that it was possible to preserve it.
Further on was a glass case surrounded by an
iron railing, in it, on a piece of black velvet
—the gem of the whole Museum—Mrs.
"Bill" Stewart's glasses. Standing before
the case, I could almost hear her say, "Now
Mr. — you have not gotten that beaker
clean, you will have to wash it again." What
was that funny noise? It was only the
alarm-clock.

FRESHMAN BANQUET (?)
One of the most interesting happenings at
the University since the last issue of the
NEws-LETTER, took place on Friday, May
1st. On this day there was held in Donovan
Hall a meeting of the United Charities of
Baltimore. One of the best caterers in town
was entrusted with the care of providing refreshments, and many delectable dainties were
prepared for the guests. A very large crowd
had been expected, but only a comparatively
small number came. Many of the undergraduates found it convenient to attend this meeting as, oddly enough, the time for holding it
coincidedly exactly with the lunch hour of
many of our young men. In fact, the occasion proved a "salad day" for many of us,
and we trust that this worthy charity will
arrange to hold many such gatherings at the
University. We would like to ask that a
notice be posted several days in advance, so
that the representation of the University may
be as large as possible. Great regret was expressed at the absence of the Dean and other
members of the Faculty who would doubtless
enjoy attending these meetings as highly as
the average undergraduate. We are not able
to find words to express our appreciation of
the hospitality so freely extended by this
most liberal of charities, and heartily hope
we may be present at several similar gatherings during the remainder of the year.

UNIVERSITY NOTES.
SENSATION IN BIOLOGY MINOR.

DR. ANDREWS OFFERS AN AVENUE OF ESCAPE
FOR TIM STUDENTS.

Before the opening of the class in Biology
Minor, Dr. Andrews startled the class by the
announcement that he contemplated opening
a kindergarten in whittling. Doubtless he
thought this would be a valuable addition to
his already organized modelling class.
The doctor stated that some ambitious
students amused themselves by carving upon
the arms of their chairs. Diagrams of thirdday chicks be said were likely to confuse the
incoming class in Biology. However, he said,
as some of the students seemed unable to
restrain their instincts, he had supplied a
large amount of pine, oak and cherry, and
that those who found the lectures too boring,
might go outside.
[N. I3.—The author, of this, did not wait
to hear more].

Dr. T. W. Clocker, Assistant in Political
Economy, has been appointed Assistant Head
of the Research Department in the School for
Social Workers at Boston. The School for
Social Workers is maintained by Simmons
College and Harvard University. Dr. Jeffrey
R. Brackett, formerly of Baltimore, is Director
of the School. As Assistant Head of the
Research Department, Dr. Glocker will help
in the direction of the investigation into the
causes of poverty, which is being carried on
under a grant from the Russell Sage Foundation.

THE MEET WITH DICKINSON.
Our dual meet with Dickinson this year was
a great success, and the overwhelming manner in which the Varsity track team defeated
the visitors more than offsets the recent defeat
at the hands of the Navy. All of our men
were in fine condition. This is shown by
the fact that the wearers of the black and
blue scored first place in twelve out of the
thirteen events, the single exception being the
victory of Hess, for Dickinson, in the shotput.
Stollenwerck, Baily and Stewart captured
all the dash and middle distance events easily,
while Captain Brenton captured everything in
sight in the distance events. Bridgman must
also come in for his share of the honors, as he
came first in the 120-yard hurdles and the
pole-vault.
Our track team will go down to Virginia
tomorrow for a dual meet with the University
of Virginia. This will be the final track

event of the season, and let us hope that the
victory of last Saturday will be repeated.

MUSICAL CLUBS TAKE A TRIP.
At last the Musical Clubs got together and
took a trip to Waterbury, Md., which is about
ten miles from Annapolis. After much trouble,
the manager made enough fellows promise to
go on the trip. We could not hope to give a
concert without our star performer, Mr. Uhlig,
and, consequently, it was necessary to wait
until he recovered from his illness.
It was quite a novel experience. We took
the W. B. & A. electric car down to Waterbury, where we were met, not by carriages,
but by one lone man, who piloted us across
fields and along dusty country roads to the
town hall. When we arrived there everyone
was so hot that we thought we should not be
able to give the concert. However, after
cooling off for about half an hour, we opened
the performance with the University Ode, as
usual. The numbers were run off rapidly and
very successfully. During the intermission
ice cream was passed around, and we had
quite a sociable time.
After the concert we were brought back by
a special car. The car was. late leaving, and
